intro.p: Movie reviews help many people decide on whether or not they should go see a movie that they are interested in. They are a part of the larger review genre which exists because people enjoy sharing their opinions on products and many find it helpful to know other’s opinions when deciding on something. Professional reviews still have the personal opinion of the reviewer, but they also give an objective view on the product in an attempt to not have the review be completely bias. Movie reviews generally go over the plot, the actors’ performances, the soundtrack, and the visuals. Many times if those aspects of the movie are good, the reviewer’s personal opinion of the movie will be positive and vice versa. Traditionally reviews are written, but with websites such as YouTube there are now many reviews that are recorded and posted as videos. These written reviews and video reviews are both very similar, being part of the same genre, but they have a few key differences that separate them. Video reviews almost feel like a conversation with the reviewer due to the viewer being able to see and hear the reviewer, although it is a one-way conversation. Written reviews do not have this luxury and so they go into more detail about the different aspects of the movie and how well the reviewer believes they worked. One way to see these similarities and differences is to look at two positive reviews of the movie “Star Wars: The Force Awakens”, one written by Anthony Lane and the other a video created by Chris Stuckmann. “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” was a highly anticipated movie due to the popularity of the franchise, so a lot of work went into the many reviews made about it. These two reviews also try to look at the movie objectively while still giving personal opinions.

body.bodyPara: Both the written review and the video review follow the movie review genre. They talk about the general plot of the movie and how it was interesting. The reviews go over how the effects and CGI look great while not being the focus and how the sounds were great. With the newest entry in the Star Wars franchise having many new faces in its cast, both reviews talk a lot about the actors and how well they performed. Both reviewers loved the main protagonist Rey, played by Daisy Ridley. “She straps herself in, swats aside any vestige of Mark Hamill, and takes command of the movie” (Lane). Stuckmann said that “she steals the entire film”. They both liked many of the new actors as well as the actors from the original Star Wars trilogy, namely Harrison Ford in the role of Han Solo. Both reviews mention the soundtrack and visuals being gorgeous. They mention that the movie “feels young” (Lane), that it is modern and fast paced in contrast to slower pace of past Star Wars movies. Lane mentions one scene being “a feast for the ears as well as the eyes, for it unfolds in a wintry forest. In addition to the usual throbbing hum of the weapons, you can hear the sizzle of sabre on snow, and the slicing hiss as the fighters miss their target and fell surrounding pine trees by mistake”. He calls this “genuine cinematic texture” that he says was missing from previous films (Lane). Stuckmann goes over this same point when he mentions that the movie “actually feels like a movie” (Stuckmann). The reviewers also go over the director of the movie, J.J. Abrams, and how he did a great job with the movie reassuring fans that the franchise is in good hands. Both reviews talk about it all; the plot, the director, the cast, the soundtrack, the visuals and more. They go over everything that the movie review genre calls for in a review. That is how they are similar. But these two reviews still have differences, mainly the obvious one. One is a video of someone talking about the movie and the other is just text. The written review has everything it needs to be in the movie review genre and that is all. The video review has a lot more. With the viewer being able to see and hear the reviewer talk, a video review feels a lot more personal than just reading words. Seeing their face and hearing their voice, the viewer can feel like they actually know the reviewer as a person. In Stuckmann’s video review, the viewers can hear how excited he is to be talking about the movie. His friendly tone of voice being able to see his facial expressions also help the viewer trust his opinion more. It is incredibly easy to tell that Stuckmann loved the movie and is excited to talk about it. Watching his video review is almost like hearing a trusted friend’s opinion instead of the opinion of some faceless movie critic.

p.sim: There are many similarities between the written and video movie reviews. They are both perfect examples of the movie review genre.
p.diff: But the video review is more approachable because of the fact that it is a video that lets the viewer see who the reviewer is.
p.genre: The movie review genre is clearly defined by these two reviews. It is also easy to see how they fit in the overarching review genre. Despite the differences between the written review and the video review, they are still both a part of both the movie review genre and the review genre.

Stuckmann, Chris. "Star Wars: The Force Awakens - Movie Review". YouTube. N.p., 2016. Web. 7 Oct. 2016.

report.p: This essay is about the genre of movie reviews, specifically focusing on two different forms of reviews of the same movie: Star Wars: The Force Awakens. You go into the similarities and differences of a written review and a video review. Early on, you said the movie reviews were objective, but the basis of a review is that it is subjective and based on personal opinion. In the first paragraph you write a lot about what the reviewers say in their reviews, but you don't talk much about what the content of the reviews say about the genre of reviews in general, whether it's online or written. You could speak more to what the reader/watcher of the review might take away from specific portions of the review, and maybe talk about how they might be getting other forms of input on the movie from other sources like word of mouth. Would you be more likely to see a movie if a good friend told you to go see it, or if some reviewer who you had no connection to told you to go see it. It's all about reliability of who you're talking to and whose opinions you trust. You might want to give some background on the Star Wars series and which actors play which characters instead of assuming that the reader is familiar with the movie. This could help the reader to be more impacted by the quotes you pull from the reviewers. You could maybe also talk about the irony of you not being able to convey your message as clearly as if you were making a video talking about these genres, because you argued that the video review had an easier time getting his message across without needing to use any "fancy language". I think it would be valuable to compare the genre of movie reviews to the over-arching genre of reviews in general in the conclusion. You should also add citations in the bibliography of the reviews you did, and anything else you drew from.
